I have a daughter with CP and a trache and a gastric tube. She's amazing and beloved, but also it's both expensive and difficult to swing her care. Like a child with autism, just getting her to therapy and other medical appointments is tricky. Factor in the idea that my partner and I work full time in jobs that are not flexible in terms of hours (we work in schools) and we have to continue to work those full time jobs to maintain her health benefits to pay for the appointments and therapy.... well, that's the root of our dilemma.

One impact, in addition to economics, that would also be interesting to explore is how the role of caregiver of a high needs kid effects the health of the caregivers. We take turns in having time away (90 minutes here or there for things like yoga or swimming or the gym), but even those stolen moments exhaust the other caregiver.

And because of our daughter's trache, we can't leave her with just any person. We haven't seen a movie in over 2 years because finding someone who can suction her or feed her via a g-tube is not so easy.

Bottom line remains, we wouldn't trade her for the world.

People are overweight or obese for a number of reasons, including heredity, genetics, environment, and a combination of factors.  One of those factors is an eating disorder like binge eating disorder.  However, under most insurance plans, those who suffer from this disorder have no coverage for counseling or eating disorder programs.  Also, treament for an eating disorder is ongoing.  The reason many insurance programs do not cover this?  It costs money.  However, some insurance plans gladly throw money at bariatric surgery which has an iffy success record at best and a high rate of costly complications.On the other hand, it's quite profitable for surgeons and hospitals.

This is at best a band-aid solution and will only add to our already immense health care costs. A true formula should involve education and increased public awareness regarding our diets (the failure of our food system should be at the heart of this debate) and lifestyles.

It is such a pain when that nasty Constitution gets in the way, isn't it?  I suspect that when there is a law you do not like and a Constitutional challenge is made to it, you would not call the challenge "a constitutional tack to what should have been a bipartisan solution".

Brooks, normally you make reasonable arguments, however this time you make no sense. The people have already spoken - Obamacare passed. The Supreme Court is making a decision because Republicans have taken a constitutional tack to what should have been a bipartisan solution. The individual mandate acknowledges that we have a broken form of universal healthcare that can be partly fixed by getting free riders out of the system.

Health care is not and can never be a true market based system. No one shops for which doctor offers the lowest cost to diagnose heart disease or deliver a baby. We do not go comparison shopping for a hospital when we have a broken leg or car accident. Do we really want medical practices advertising about

Ironic that you laud your Medicare (lucky you to have affordable health care while millions in the US don't). It is essentially the European system that you so disdain.

The failure of Obamacare is a simple failure of courage on the part of Obama. Had he the spine to stand up to corporate power and offer what you have to everyone in the country, he would today be riding high, and his presidency would have been rated among the very top. Now, as the SCOTUS battle ensues, he will be relegated to the mediocrity he has earned.

What you see as a fascination by those of the left with a so-called "perfect" European model is what those of us on the left see as a utter refusal by those on the right to suggest that the US is not perfect in this realm and that other countries may have seen better results with a different system. Nobody's saying to adopt any one European system. But we should be looking at what works best from all of them and then adapt that to the US. What we shouldn't be doing is declaring that dammit, we're Americans, and we don't need no stinkin' insight from those godless socialists across the Atlantic.

That'd be like the Norwegians finding the cure for cancer and then declaring that we Americans won't use it because we can find a better cure through our sheer force of will and exceptionalism.

You have a strong argument for your view and I concur. As a senior and a consumer of the best healthcare system in the world, my experience with Medicare plus supplementary Blue Cross has been outstanding. To ensure that, proactive involvement by the patient is required, which is not availed of by everyone, or is unavailable where one lives, which leads to disappointment.

The fascination with European models quoted as perfect, does not hold up to close scrutiny, most especially in both the UK and Ireland, where under their National Health systems radical rationing of major care is a fact of life. To be assured of top flight coverage by expert practitioners in a timely manner people carry substantial personal private insurance coverage. In Ireland, granted due to the economic crisis, huge cutbacks have been implemented in the National Health plan, which the government arbitrarily dictated using the crisis as the reason. Could that happen here in the future ?

The key for seniors to benefit from Medicare is to choose an integrated health care provider, such as a University hospital system, for all of your needs. Ones records are available to all of the doctors you will need and it is easy for them to monitor and provide excellent care. Obamacare will profit from that example and with the results from the SCOTUS hearing will make a viable system work well. Obamacare is like a patchwork quilt and satisfies few. The process was at fault and people have been upset ever since.
